persons.name: René JustHaüy
persons.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: Land's End
places.description: Land's End is a headland on the west coast of Cornwall. It is the most westerly point of mainland England. The underlying rock at Land's End is granite.

places.name: Aswan
places.description: a city on the Nile River, which has been southern Egypt’s strategic and commercial gateway since antiquity. Davy refers to it as "Sienna in Egypt" possibly a misspelling of its former name Syene, from which the name of the rock sienite is derived.

places.name: Killiney
places.description: Killiney is a coastal area of County Dublin, Ireland. In the 19th Century it was a popular seaside resort and many of the pebbles and rocks along Killiney Beach are examples of carboniferous limestone, some of which contain fossils of corals, sea shells and other sea life that existed millions of years ago.

places.name: Iran

places.name: Kamchatka Krai
places.description: The Kamchatka Peninsula is a 1,250-kilometre-long peninsula in the Russian Far East.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.
